Logically, the code is also correct. Here's what it does:

1. `nums = []` creates an empty list called `nums`.
2. `vals = nums` makes `vals` reference the same list object as `nums`. They are essentially two names pointing to the same list.
3. `vals.append(1)` appends the integer 1 to the list referenced by `vals`. Since `vals` and `nums` point to the same list, this operation also modifies `nums`.

After the code runs, both `nums` and `vals` will be `[1]`. They are references to the same list object, so they will always have the same length.

The code demonstrates that in Python, when you assign one list to another variable, it creates a new reference to the same list object, rather than creating a new copy of the list.
